match.venue: National Cricket Stadium, St George's, Grenada

commentary.line: So that's it then from us here. England finally win an overseas Test. They will be overjoyed. West Indies have some work to do before the next one in Barbados on May 1st. That should be a pacy pitch and a result-oriented one (hopefully). We enjoyed bringing you this game. Hope you did too, reading our coverage of it. Cricket continues on, there is the IPL which is going on. So do join us tomorrow to follow all that. Until then it is goodbye from us. Remember to be well and take care. Also to sleep tight. Alvida!

Cook: 'The most important thing was an England win. To get 20 wickets on such a flat wicket was a great effort. Lot of skill involved. To get six wickets in that morning session really set us up. It was all about putting the ball in the right area with the right intensity. Credit to Jimmy, what an outstanding spell that was, don't know whether it was 8 or 9 overs in that heat - it was a testament to his skill and his fitness. Can't fault the lads at all today and over the five days. Fantastic from Rooty and Gary. I didn't realise his record was so good for the last 15 months or so (talking about Root). They (Root and Gary) have taken run making to a new level for England. I dropped Samuels on 30. It was costly, he played really well. They probably got 50 too many in the conditions that we had in our favor. At the end of the day we got 470 and bowled them out for 300. That set the game up for us there. The lads were brilliant. The wickets we have played on in the first two Tests have been very slow and hard to force a result. It has been a hell of a lot of hard work for the last 10 days and we got the reward today. Thanks to the Barmy Army, the hotels are full at the minute and also for our families who have been here. We love playing for England and we are doing it in front of them as well - it is brilliant.'

Ramdin: 'We fought hard for the first four days but that one session where we lost 6 wickets really cost us the game. I'm not quite sure, when you have teams in a position where you can win or draw you should take the initiative. But that spell from Anderson in the morning took it away from us. The batters who got in need to carry on. It is difficult for a new batsman to go in and face the new ball. But that's how it goes. The England team stuck at it, they went out there and executed their plans. It was tough conditions to go out there and play our strokes. As the game went along the pitch got better for them. Slight injury to Holder, hopefully he will rest and get back out strong for the next game.'

Root: 'Feels a lot better now with the win behind us. Last night and throughout today we have been ruthless and it is great to take something forward into the summer. Just wanted to be busy from the off and tried to make it hard for the guys to bowl at me early on in my innings. It got me going anyway. Lot of credit has to go to the way the openers played. There are so many positives to take out for our side from this game and we are chomped at the bits to get back out there at Barbados. Probably being left out. That's the worst thing I had to deal with in cricket - Cookie coming up to me and telling me that I was not playing. Never want to be in that position again. So get greedy and get whatever runs I can. Something that Graham Gooch told us when I came into the team - to get daddy hundreds. Something we all aspire to do in the dressing room and something we would look to do in the summer. No, not really. Part of the game I'm afraid. Being involved in three other run outs and called a former Yorkshire and England batsman - we will see how things go.' (in response to Athers' question on whether he had a word with Anderson after that run out)
Joe Root is the Man of the Match

England had a session and a half to get to the target of 143 and they did so without much fuss. Cook and Ballance brought up their second fifties on the trot and scored at a good rate to help the hosts over the line comfortably in the end. The visitors won the second Test by nine wickets to take a 1-0 lead in the three-match series, which ensured the retention of the Wisden Trophy.

Kraigg Brathwaite scored a fine century on day 4 and was supported well by Darren Bravo and Marlon Samuels as they frustrated the England bowlers, who struggled on a slow and flat track. However, James Anderson's inspired spell on the final day helped England bowl out West Indies for 307 just after lunch. Anderson finished with 4/43 which included three scalps on day 5 while he also took two catches and effected a run out.

In reply, England were slow but steady with Alastair Cook and Jonathan Trott registering patient half-centuries and bringing up their maiden century stand for the opening wicket. Gary Ballance too shone in the first essay with a knock of 77, but it was Joe Root who was the best of the lot as he came up with terrific 182. He was unfortunate to miss out on a double hundred, running out of partners to be stranded when England were bowled out for 464, finishing with a 165-run lead. Bishoo, playing his first Test in three years, picked up a four-wicket haul.

Match recap: West Indies did not get off to the best of starts after being inserted on day one, and were put on the back foot straightaway as they suffered a top-order collapse. On the rain-curtailed opening day, England were calling all the shots until Marlon Samuels bailed the hosts out of trouble. Rain made Samuels wait for a while on day 2 before he went on to register his seventh Test ton. However a loss in concentration resulted in his dismissal while the middle order batsmen failed to come up with anything substantial and England were back on top again. However, the visitors took a while to separate the last wicket pair of Devendra Bishoo and Shannon Gabriel, who added 52 runs to take West Indies to one short of 300. Stuart Broad was the top wicket-taker for England in the first innings, finishing with 4/61.

From that point on the result was a mere formality and England duly completed proceedings to win. Runs for Ballance and Cook and that should please the English set-up. Also winning an overseas Test after 10 attempts will bring cheer to their camp. West Indies saved the game in Antigua but a poor morning session here has seen them go 0-1 down in the series. We will have the match summary first and then the presentation to follow. Do stay tuned...

Handshakes all around. Smiles in the England camp. Anderson the man of the moment walks out and hugs Ballance and Cook. Stokes salutes to Ottis Gibson in celebration. That was Stokes taking the mickey out of Samuels. West Indies fought hard for four days but one bad session today cost the game. They came apart against one man - Anderson in particular who had a hand in all the six dismissals in the morning session

41.1   Samuels to Ballance, FOUR, England win! Ballance and Cook punch the air in delight. First overseas win for them since December 2012 when they beat India at Kolkata. Short and wide outside off, Ballance cuts late and beats point diving to his right. The ball races away. Ballance and Cook grab stumps as souvenirs and walk off. Well done!

Welcome back. Last session of the game and how long will England take to knock this off? I'm going for 16 overs. Let's see. Bishoo has the ball. From over the wicket

Since then, it has been a sedate innings from both Ballance and Cook, who have a lot of overs in hand to chase this total down. Half an hour before the tea break, Holder had to be stretchered off after he twisted his ankle while landing in his delivery stride. The only other chance West Indies had was when Ballance edged Samuels, but Devon Smith at first slip put it down. England are almost on the verge of taking a 1-0 lead in the series. Can West Indies pull off a miraculous escape? Looks unlikely but not impossible. Join us in a short while to find out.

Tea, Day 5: The West Indians tried to put up a front at the start of the session, but Moeen Ali got the final two wickets in the same over. Both decisions were reviewed and went in favour of the Englishmen. England then came out to bat and lost Trott in the second over of the innings, with Shannon Gabriel sending him back for a duck.

Holder should be a big doubt for the next Test which starts on the 1st of May. Samuels now comes on to finish the over

Still Holder is down. An icepack being applied to Holder's ankle. Cook and Ballance have a drink in the middle. Holder is dragged into a stretcher. Swelling on the left ankle and he is being taken on a stretcher off the field. Cook pats him as he is taken off. Nice to see. A couple of England support staff help Holder off the field

Holder landed awkwardly on the left-ankle and twisted it badly. His body gave way and he is in severe pain. Not a good sight to see at all on a cricket field. The drinks have been called for. The physio is having a look at the ankle. The umpires are monitoring the situation. Coming back to the shot, it went straight through Samuels' hands at mid-wicket. Was a tough chance but could've been taken. Now the stretcher is being called for

Cook and Trott are at the crease. Cook is on strike. Roach will open the attack
The roller is off the pitch and we should start now. It has been 16 minutes since the innings ended. Roach from round the wicket to Cook. Here we go...

Phil Simmons is the man giving the pep talk this time not Curtly Ambrose. Trott stands in front of a window and shadow practices his defensive shots. Cook sits there calmly. Delay due to an issue with the heavy roller. It didn't come on immediately at the end of the innings. Still Cook and Trott wait. Out they come now...
The heavy roller is doing its job. The West Indian players patiently wait on the sidelines. Heavy music blaring out of the speakers at the stadium

England walk off as a team content at finishing off the innings. Before lunch it was the Anderson show and then after it Moeen Ali took two in an over to hasten the innings break. England need 143 in 59 overs to go 1-0 up. All the damage was done in the first session. Now up to Cook, Trott and Co. to finish the job with the bat. We will be back shortly with England's chase...

Moeen Ali to S Gabriel, THATS OUT!! Lbw!!

Gabriel is out lbw as well. He is reviewing it. He was walking off. But Devendra Bishoo forced him to review. Regulation offie, Gabriel misses the clip and it is hitting him high on the pad. No inside edge onto the pads. Waiting for Hawk-Eye now. Hitting leg and the on-field call will stay

Moeen Ali to Ramdin, THATS OUT!! Lbw!!

No inside edge onto the pads too. Hawk-Eye will confirm that it is hitting middle of middle. Ramdin is gone

Can West Indies hang in long enough to force a draw? Or will England go 1-0 up? The post-lunch session will have all the answers. Do join us then. We will back soon...

The new ball was England's hope and they made it count. Anderson was outstanding and the other bowlers responded in kind. The last three wickets of Blackwood, Holder and Roach were gifts to England. Irresponsible from West Indies and all the hard work put in during the Test seems to be going waste. Phil Simmons won't be a happy man looking at how his side have capitulated. Someone needs to hang in with Ramdin or else England will have an easy chase

It was the Jimmy Anderson session. He had a hand in all the dismissals today. Six wickets fell today. Three were taken by Anderson. Brathwaite to a short ball, Chanderpaul edging to slip. Samuels caught behind. Then took a good catch to get Blackwood out. Ran Holder out with a sharp direct hit and ended the session with Roach's catch at mid-on. If there is a perfect session for one man, this has to be it. Anderson couldn't put a foot wrong today.

The players are out there in the middle. England were in a huddle with Cook leading the talking. Root to start off the final day's play. Again brilliant day to begin. Bright, sunny and not a cloud in the sky. Root will come from round the wicket first up

For now, the priority for West Indies will be to save this game. With Samuels at the crease, there will be no shortage of banter as well. Even though Stokes kept quiet yesterday, don't count on him to stay like that today. Surely, we will see a few words being exchanged between the both of them if Samuels stays put. A cracking day of Test cricket is ahead of us. Stay tuned.

England might have just picked up two wickets yesterday, but it's a new day today. If they can pick a few early wickets today, they will put the men from Caribbean under pressure. At the same time, a West Indian win looks very unlikely with the current scenario. If they are to win this game, they will have to bat remarkably well and score really quickly. In addition to that, they will have to take 10 English wickets and all this looks a fair way away from the position they are in right now.

Hello and welcome to the fifth and final day of the second Test between West Indies and England. The game might be headed for a draw, but there's no shortage of excitement. Riding on Brathwaite's ton yesterday, West Indies managed to go past England's lead. Currently, the West Indians are ahead by 37 runs, with Brathwaite and Samuels at the crease.

This Test looks headed towards a draw. But England will have a new cherry in five overs time. One final effort with that and if they get quick wickets, they might still win the game. For that to happen the pitch has to aid them as well. West Indies would be looking to bat on and make the game safe. It sets up a beautiful final day. We will be there to bring you all the action. Hope you've enjoyed today's coverage. Until tomorrow it's goodbye from here. Sleep tight! Adios!

They tried to get Kraigg Brathwaite and Samuels out with the leg-trap late on asking Jordan and Anderson to target the stumps. Jordan reversed it and caused uncomfortable situations for the batsmen during that phase, but the West Indian pair held on. Off the penultimate over of the day, Brathwaite got his fourth Test ton. The one battle that everyone expected to see today between Samuels and Stokes proved to be an anti-climax as Stokes kept quiet. Unusually calm and subdued. As was Samuels. Maybe we might see something rev up tomorrow.

Earlier in the day, England in search of quick runs went after the bowling and lost wickets. Root tried to reach his maiden double hundred but sloppy running from Anderson put paid to that. The lead was 165 and they got Devon Smith out early. But since then Kraigg Brathwaite has stood firm, first building a partnership with Darren Bravo and then with Samuels. The pitch was flat and England's bowlers toiled hard without any significant reward.

Stokes comes in and shakes Kraigg Brathwaite's hand. Moeen Ali pats the young man. Phil Simmons looks a pleased man. The day has belonged to the 22-year old opener from Barbados - Kraigg Brathwaite. He has steered his side to stumps just two down with a technically brilliant hundred. Immense powers of concentration shown and his temperament was first-rate. Looks a player who is born to bat in Test cricket. Whatever England tried at him he has had an answer.

Big appeal for lbw. Given not out. England review. Is that ball doing too much? Or is it hitting the stumps flush on? No problems with the front foot although Jordan has a milimetre of his foot behind the line. Bowden the third umpire. Billy is looking at the front foot. Wants to be sure that Jordan hasn't overstepped. He is happy with that. So we move on. Nips back in and raps Kraigg Brathwaite high on the pads, above the kneeroll. No inside edge onto the pads. Height might save Brathwaite here. Wait! The front-on replay shows a tiny inside edge. So Brathwaite lives on

Welcome back...

There are 36 overs scheduled to be bowled in the final session. Can England come back strongly? Or will these two grind out another wicketless session? We'll know shortly. Do join us for the post-tea session in a few minutes time

That will be tea. West Indies fought back superbly in that session. 100 runs and no wickets in 33 overs. England toiled hard but there was to be no breakthrough. Kraigg Brathwaite and Darren Bravo dug in and ensured when the bad ball came they put it away. The deficit is now just 43 and West Indies will hope for a similar final session to go into the final day in the lead.

Jordan replaces Broad for the time being

The groundstaff are out on the field as they fix the issue with Stuart Broad's landing area before he gets into the delivery stride. A little piece of artificial turf is being put into place. Broad and the umpire watch on as the groundstaff nail it down using a hammer.

12.6   J Anderson to Kraigg Brathwaite, no run, another short delivery outside off, Brathwaite was again in two minds whether to duck or play at that. In the end, he drops his wrists and allows it to go through to the keeper
12.5   J Anderson to Kraigg Brathwaite, no run, back of a length delivery slightly wide outside off, Brathwaite rides the bounce and defends it into the off-side
12.4   J Anderson to Kraigg Brathwaite, no run, bumper from Anderson, Brathwaite is happy to duck under that
12.3   J Anderson to Kraigg Brathwaite, no run, bowls it slightly wide outside off, Brathwaite goes chasing after it and tries to have a dab at it, fails to make a connection though

A leg gully has been put in place now
12.1   J Anderson to Kraigg Brathwaite, no run, back of a length delivery just outside off, Brathwaite defends it towards the point region
Anderson and Cook were having a discussion about who to bowl. They decide that Anderson will bowl another over for now at least
11.6   Broad to Kraigg Brathwaite, 1 run, angling in on off and middle, Brathwaite goes across slightly and works it past mid-wicket for a single
11.5   Broad to Kraigg Brathwaite, no run, back of a length delivery on the stumps, Brathwaite defends it into the on-side

11.4   Broad to Kraigg Brathwaite, no run, banged in short and outside off, Brathwaite was in two minds there whether to fend in into the on-side, he hops with the bounce and decides to play at it, the ball takes the glove on its way and falls just short of Cook at first slip, who was diving forward
11.3   Broad to Kraigg Brathwaite, no run, full and around off, Brathwaite leans into the drive, the fielder at cover dives to his right and makes a good stop. Saved four runs for his team there

11.2   Broad to Kraigg Brathwaite, no run, back of a length delivery outside off, Brathwaite hops a little and punches it to the left of the bowler, the fielder from cover runs across to his right and prevents the single
11.1   Broad to Kraigg Brathwaite, no run, just short of a good length and outside off, Brathwaite punches it to the right of cover, the fielder moves across and stops the ball

10.5   J Anderson to Darren Bravo, no run, full and on the stumps, Bravo defends it to cover
10.4   J Anderson to Darren Bravo, no run, length delivery angling away outside off, Bravo shoulders arms
10.3   J Anderson to Darren Bravo, no run, Anderson bangs this halfway down the wicket, Bravo sits under it and the keeper collects
10.2   J Anderson to Darren Bravo, no run, good shot for no run! It was full on off, Bravo leans forward and drives, but picks out cover to perfection
10.1   J Anderson to Darren Bravo, no run, angling away outside off, Bravo lets that one go through to the keeper
Broad has some issues with the footmarks just before his delivery stride. He is currently having a chat with the umpire and doesn't look pleased at all.
9.6   Broad to Kraigg Brathwaite, no run, full delivery on the pad, Brathwaite clips it to BSL, who bends down and stops the ball, the ball just bounced in front of him there
Comes round the wicket now
9.5   Broad to Kraigg Brathwaite, no run, length delivery outside off, Brathwaite defends it into the off-side
9.4   Broad to Kraigg Brathwaite, no run, bumper from Broad that swings away late after going past the batsman, Brathwaite ducks under it and the keeper takes it

9.2   Broad to Kraigg Brathwaite, no run, angling in on middle and leg, Brathwaite nudges it towards mid-wicket, who dives to his left and stops the ball

Broad is still not happy with something. Maybe, he wants a particular set of shoes from the dressing room

8.6   J Anderson to Kraigg Brathwaite, 1 run, back of a length delivery on the pads, Brathwaite tucks it to the right of short leg fielder, the ball rolls away to fine leg and the batsmen take a single. It was in the air for a little while but far away from the reach of the fielder

8.2   J Anderson to Kraigg Brathwaite, no run, back of a length delivery outside off, Brathwaite hangs back and defends it into the off-side
8.1   J Anderson to Kraigg Brathwaite, no run, banged in short and at the batsman, Brathwaite ducks under it
Broad has called the twelfth man to have a chat. Don't know what it's about. It might have to do something with his run-up.
7.6   Broad to Darren Bravo, no run, full delivery angled across off, Bravo looks to drive, gets an inside edge that rolls away to square leg
7.5   Broad to Darren Bravo, no run, full and angling away outside off, Bravo is happy to let that one go through
7.4   Broad to Darren Bravo, no run, short of length delivery on the stumps, Bravo defends off the back foot
Two slips and a gully in place for Bravo

7.3   Broad to Kraigg Brathwaite, 1 run, length delivery with a hint of shape away just outside off, Brathwaite pushes it in front of cover and sets off, the batsmen complete the single comfortably in the end

Broad will share the attack with Anderson. Three slips and a gully in place for him as well.
Stuart Broad [2.0-0-7-0] is back into the attack
6.6   J Anderson to Darren Bravo, FOUR, on the pads this time, Bravo stays back and tickles it to the fine leg fence

6.5   J Anderson to Darren Bravo, no run, full delivery with a hint of outswing just outside off, Bravo pushes at it, gets a thick outside edge that rolls away towards gully, who dives to his left and stops the ball

6.2   J Anderson to Darren Bravo, no run, full and shaping away outside off, Bravo lifts his bat and lets it go
6.1   J Anderson to Kraigg Brathwaite, 1 run, back of a length delivery slightly wide outside off, Brathwaite knocks it through the covers and the batsmen cross over for a single
Welcome back. The players are making their way out to the middle. Anderson will start the proceedings after lunch. Three slips and a gully in place. Here we go then...

Devon Smith fell to Anderson which further dented West Indies' session. England have their tails up and after lunch they will be looking for more inroads. We will be back with the post-lunch session to see whether they can do that. Or will West Indies fightback with the bat? Do join us shortly to follow all the action...

Root and Anderson walk off patting each other. I'm sure Root must have reminded Anderson about his sloppy running that potentially cost the Yorkshireman his double ton. It has been England's session. They stretched the lead to 165 as Root farmed the strike along with his partners. He was set for a double ton but Anderson's poor running cost him that. England were always on the lookout for quick runs with the batting they had down the order. Buttler, Jordan weren't going to hang around. The lead was substantial and West Indies had a nervy 25 minutes to face before lunch.
5.6   Moeen Ali to Darren Bravo, no run, tossed up outside off, Darren Bravo smothers it and that will be lunch on day 4
5.5   Moeen Ali to Darren Bravo, no run, flighted delivery on middle and leg, Darren Bravo dead-bats it down the track

5.4   Moeen Ali to Darren Bravo, FOUR, bad delivery and Darren Bravo puts it away. High full toss on the stumps, swung away through mid-wicket. More off a thick inside half but into the vacant area. Consecutive boundaries
A field change as Moeen Ali takes his time

5.3   Moeen Ali to Darren Bravo, FOUR, Darren Bravo isn't going to hold back. This may be the last over before lunch but he sees the flighted delivery outside off and goes over Moeen Ali's head. Hit hard and over the bowler

5.2   Moeen Ali to Darren Bravo, 2 runs, loose from Darren Bravo. Goes after a tossed up delivery outside off, gets a thick outside edge, just wide of the outstretched left-hand of the diving gully. Didn't even get a finger on it. Broad chases and keeps it to two
Slip, gully and a short leg in place
5.1   Moeen Ali to Darren Bravo, no run, low full toss from round the wicket, driven back to Moeen Ali
Moeen Ali, right-arm off break, comes into the attack
4.6   J Anderson to Kraigg Brathwaite, no run, surprise short delivery, outside off, Kraigg Brathwaite plays it well, dropping his gloves and swaying away from the line of that
4.5   J Anderson to Kraigg Brathwaite, 2 runs, full and inswinging, tailing back in late, Kraigg Brathwaite flicks through mid-wicket. Didn't fall over
We may get in one more over before lunch
4.4   J Anderson to Darren Bravo, 1 run, down leg, Darren Bravo tucks it through square leg for a comfortable single

4.1   J Anderson to Kraigg Brathwaite, no run, full and targetting off, Kraigg Brathwaite brings the bat down and defends to short cover
3.6   Broad to Darren Bravo, no run, way outside off, easy leave

3.5   Broad to Darren Bravo, FOUR, flicked with a flourish by Darren Bravo. Broad has his hands on his head. It was full and swinging in, Darren Bravo flicked it to the left of mid-wicket. Was in the air but well wide of the fielder
3.4   Broad to Darren Bravo, no run, pushed across Darren Bravo on a fuller length, he gets forward and shoulders arms
3.3   Broad to Darren Bravo, no run, short of length on the stumps, nudged to mid-wicket
3.2   Broad to Kraigg Brathwaite, 1 run, short of length on the stumps, tucked through mid-wicket for a comfortable single
3.1   Broad to Kraigg Brathwaite, no run, full and outside off, holds its line too, Kraigg Brathwaite shoulders arms

Four slips and a gully in now
2.5   J Anderson to Darren Bravo, no run, big outswinger, Darren Bravo shoulders arms
Darren Bravo, left handed bat, comes to the crease

2.4   J Anderson to Devon Smith, out Bowled!! The leg stump is knocked out. What a bad leave that is. Off the inside edge. Devon Smith was shouldering arms to a big outswinger, it pitched around off and was moving, Smith was late in leaving and the ball takes the edge of the hanging bat and takes out the leg pole. Bad start for West Indies. Dream one for England. Devon Smith b J Anderson 2(7)
J Anderson to Devon Smith, THATS OUT!! Bowled!!
2.3   J Anderson to Kraigg Brathwaite, 1 run, there comes the big inswinger, hoops back in from a short of length, Kraigg Brathwaite jabs it awkwardly to the right of square leg, quick single taken
The ball is swinging for Anderson, but the length is short. Needs to get it further up

Stuart Broad, right-arm fast medium, comes into the attack
0.6   J Anderson to Kraigg Brathwaite, no run, tight maiden from Anderson, short of length outside off, defended from the crease to gully

0.4   J Anderson to Kraigg Brathwaite, no run, now on off stump, Kraigg Brathwaite shuffles across in defence

0.2   J Anderson to Kraigg Brathwaite, no run, bit of shape away, from a good length outside off, Kraigg Brathwaite has a sighter and lets it go
Three slips and a gully in
0.1   J Anderson to Kraigg Brathwaite, no run, good length on the stumps, a loosener, Kraigg Brathwaite nudges it to short mid-wicket
Kraigg Brathwaite and Devon Smith are at the crease. Kraigg Brathwaite is on strike. J Anderson will open the attack

The England team are in a huddle. Cook has a few words to say. Brathwaite and Devon Smith walk out. A tricky 25 minutes or so for them. Anderson and Broad will come full throttle before lunch. The heavy roller is rolling the pitch. Anderson is at the top of his mark. Broad is there next to him. Brathwaite is marking his guard Chanders style - hammering the bail into the pitch

So England finish with a lead of 165. West Indies have more than four sessions to bat out a draw. They did it in the last game. Can they do it again here? Personally I'm looking forward to Stokes v Samuels. It should be unmissable

144.1   J Holder to J Root, out J Anderson Run Out!! 1 run completed. It was flicked towards deep mid-wicket, Root always wanted two but Anderson was struggling. The throw was poor - high and to the left of Holder, who leapt and used his height to good effect. Catches it with one hand and flicks it back onto the stumps. Anderson didn't even dive or plonk his bat in. Was caught short. The feet too didn't get in. Bad running and it has cost Root a potential double hundred. Root is not a happy chappy. But he has played superbly. J Anderson run out (S Gabriel/J Holder) 2(12)
J Holder to J Root, THATS OUT!! Run Out!!

Anderson is out. In a comical way too. Run out. He didn't even attempt to dive in. Anderson runs off. No double ton for Root. End of the innings. Root walks off raising his bat to all corners of the crowd. A few English WAGS applaud his effort. Root is unhappy after Anderson got out. He showed off his displeasure as he hit the turf with his bat. Threw his helmet away after crossing the ropes.
The batsmen take a drink

143.5   Devendra Bishoo to J Root, 1 run, flighted delivery outside off, Root gets forward and drives to long-off

Now Anderson needs to see off three balls in this over

Root and Anderson have a word

With that wicket drinks have been taken. West Indies have taken three wickets in that hour. But Root has moved to 150. With Anderson at the crease, he will go for it
James Anderson, left handed bat, comes to the crease

137.5   Devendra Bishoo to Broad, out Caught by Devon Smith!! Good anticipation from Devon Smith at slip. He saw Broad shaping for the sweep and moved to his left, the ball looped off the wrist band that was part of the glove and Smith caught it at a leg slip position. Broad reviewed it but the original decision stood. Broad c Devon Smith b Devendra Bishoo 0(4)
Devendra Bishoo to Broad, THATS OUT!! Caught!!

Caught at slip. Given out and Broad is reviewing it. He thinks it has come off the forearm. How long will Billy take for this? Let's see. The front foot is fine. Straight off the glove as Broad went for the sweep. Broad may well be gone. It has come off the wrist band which is part of the glove. Steve Davis should stand by his original decision. Broad is unhappy. He is taking his time to go off. A send-off from a few West Indians. Billy gave it out much sooner than the previous decision.

137.3   Devendra Bishoo to J Root, FOUR, 150 for Root. He raises his bat. Flighted on middle and leg, Root plays a hard slog sweep wide of the square leg umpire, beats deep backward square to his left. Fourth score of 150+ in Tests for Root

136.3   Roach to J Root, out Jordan Run Out!! 1 run completed. Root has done in Jordan. It was steered off the front foot to the left of sweeper cover, Root wanted two then sent Jordan back. Jordan tried to dive and get back. Slid his bat in with the left-hand. The right-hand had the gloves and Jordan was caught inches short by a super throw. Bowden took an age to give it out and there was a technical failure on the giant screen which further delayed proceedings. Jordan run out (J Holder/Ramdin) 16(28) [4s-3]
Roach to J Root, THATS OUT!! Run Out!!

Has Jordan been run out? Looks like a close call. Jordan may well be out here. The bat looks just short of the crease as he dived to get back. Bullet throw from the deep and Ramdin had little work to do. Right over the stumps and Jordan may well be gone. Ian Bishop is giving it out. The third umpire is taking a lot of replays to come to a decision. Billy Bowden the man. If Bowden is taking so long, Jordan may well get the BOD. It is four minutes and counting. Decision still pending. The giant screen flashes out finally. After four minutes and forty seconds to be exact. A mini break that. Jordan walks off.

The players are walking out to the middle. The umpires are already there. Curtly Ambrose has a pep talk to his boys as usual. He does that every day. Root and Buttler walk out. We are starting 15 minutes early. It will be an extended session. Gabriel will begin. Two slips and a gully in place

Pitch report: The actual surface looks very very good. It is a little whiter than at the start. There won't be much assistance for the bowlers. Hard work for the bowlers. Maybe a bit of turn as the game goes on.

With Root and Buttler at the crease, England would be looking for as big a lead as possible. Another fine day in prospect and we welcome you to our coverage. It is bright and sunny today and that's good news to start off the day.

England hold the advantage going into day 4 of this second Test. Root's unbeaten hundred was the highlight of yesterday's play. But the last hour belonged to West Indies helped by England's bad cricket. Three wickets were gifted to the hosts and Samuels gave Stokes a send-off by saluting. It was brilliant from the Jamaican as he brought life late on to the day's proceedings. Those three wickets have given West Indies hope of keeping the lead to manageable proportions.

It has been a long day but a fun day - made all the more enjoyable by Samuels' theatre. Tomorrow is going to be another such day - 98 overs are scheduled to be bowled again. We will be there to bring you every ball. The fingers are aching from a long stint today. I badly need a break. Until tomorrow it's goodbye from here. Adios!

Amidst all this Root deserves special praise for the way he conducted his innings. He was calm, played all his strokes and put the bad ball away. Unfluttered and very impressive from the Yorkshireman who continued his golden run with the bat. He hardly gave West Indies a chance and remains the key for England to gain a potentially match-winning first innings lead. West Indies will be looking to get his wicket as quickly as possible tomorrow morning.

England steadily built on their lead and only the last hour brought West Indies back into the game. England though had a huge part in that, gifting three wickets to the hosts. Ballance played a loose drive, Moeen Ali ran himself out and Stokes holed out after losing the verbal battle with Samuels. The battle between Samuels and Stokes was the highlight of the day. The Jamaican seemed inspired when Stokes came on and didn't stop his antics till the all-rounder got out. No aggressive in your face celebration or anything nasty. Just a salute with no words after Stokes got out! Pure gold from Samuels! Superb drama to liven up things.

Root walks off with his bat raised. Darren Bravo comes in and shakes his hand. Samuels has a smile on his face after a hard day's work. England started the day at 74/0 and they lost Trott before lunch. Cook was set to get a hundred but chopped one off Gabriel who dismissed Ian Bell the same way in his next over. Those two wickets in quick succession energised West Indies but Root and Ballance put on a partnership. Slightly bizzare tactics by West Indies as they overbowled Bishoo - who bowled 22 overs at one stretch either side of lunch. Also West Indies didn't take the new ball till the 87th over when it was crying out to be taken.

Welcome back...

Tea, Day 3: Gabriel removed both Cook and Bell in quick succession to keep the hosts in the hunt. Ballance and Root couldn't get going initially, but they batted sensibly to give England the upper hand again. Ramdin used some strange tactics as he bowled Devendra Bishoo for 22 overs unchanged either side of lunch. The leg-spinner got tired and eventually was taken off the attack. Root then upped the ante and recorded his 6th successive 50-plus score in Tests. It was also surprising to see that West Indies did not opt for the second new ball straightaway. So England in firm control at the moment. West Indies need some quick wickets, otherwise the visitors could run away with a big first innings lead.

90.6   S Gabriel to Ballance, no run, close shave for Ballance. He hangs back to this good length delivery, tries to defend, misses and the ball hits him just above the knee roll, height was the only issue there and it was just clipping the top of the stumps. It needed to crash into the stumps for the onfield call to be overturned

Appeal for LBW, not given and West Indies have reviewed. Gabriel was so confident and he wanted his captain to send it upstairs. No issues with Gabriel's footing. There is no inside edge as well. This is interesting. Is it too high? Is it sliding down the leg side? Oh the Hawk-Eye says umpire's call as it clips the top of middle and leg.

Welcome back.. Another long hard session awaits the West Indies unless they pick up quick wickets. Gabriel it will be to restart. Two slips and a gully. From round the wicket first up

England would look to get as many as they can in the first innings and put West Indies under pressure as the match heads towards its climax. We will be back soon to see whether they can press forward. Do join us then for the post-lunch session

That will be lunch on day 3. It has been slow progress as only 69 have been scored in that session off 34 overs. It was an extended session today as well to make up time for the rain delay over the course of the opening two days - we had a prompt start unlike yesterday. Glorious bright day and West Indies toiled hard without any reward till Bishoo got Trott out. Bishoo had a close review go against him as Cook survived. The odd ball is turning and some are gripping. We saw Samuels getting the ball to bounce occasionally. It is certainly helping the spinners and will continue to do so as the match goes on. Tough times ahead for West Indies

Given not out for an lbw. West Indies review. Has Cook got outside the line? Turns in and strikes Cook low on the pads. Height won't be an issue. Impact key here. No inside edge onto the pads. Still no Hawk-Eye in. West Indies seem confident. As I assumed it is umpire's call and it is. Cook survives. But barely just. Clipping top of middle.

Our man - Bharath R digs this stat out for us. This is the first time in Tests since November 2010 when Dilshan and Paranavitana put on 102 at Galle that West Indies have conceded 100 for the opening wicket. Astounding really and shows how the West Indian new ball bowlers have inevitably provided a breakthrough
Drinks time. Hard work for West Indies. Nothing in the pitch to help them and England are in prime position. A chance for Trott and Cook to dig in and get big runs. Lovely day for batting as well

The players are out in the middle. Trott is scratching his guard as always. Gabriel will start off the day with the ball. Three slips and a gully in place.

West Indies would want their pacers, Kemar Roach, Shannon Gabriel and Jason Holder, to bowl a much fuller length than yesterday. We saw that yesterday that the length they bowled to both Alastair Cook and Jonathan Trott was not full enough to draw them forward. There is a bit of assistance for the spinners and West Indies would look up to Devendra Bishoo to get some vital breakthroughs alongside Marlon Samuels.

Welcome to day three of the second Test. I have great news for you folks. Unlike the first two days, it is bright and sunny at the ground and we will have a prompt start. There is a lot of blue sky around and it should be a good day for batting. If England do well in the first few minutes of the morning session, they should be able to post a big score and gain a sizeable first innings lead.

It is safe to say that England have the upper hand at the moment, but things could change dramatically, especially if the ball swings around in the morning session tomorrow. To make up lost time, play will begin 15 minutes earlier at 09:45 local time. Looking forward to your company then. Goodbye!

Earlier, Marlon Samuels, who started the day on 94, took a long time and was also interrupted by rain breaks, before finally completing his 7th Test hundred. However, he threw it away soon after. With West Indies losing 4 wickets for 24 runs, things looked very bad, but a handy fifty partnership between Bishoo and Gabriel for the last wicket helped West Indies post 299. Stuart Broad was the pick of the bowlers for England today and he finished with 4 wickets. James Anderson and Chris Jordan bagged two wickets apiece.

Stumps, Day 2: Having bowled West Indies out for 299, England have made a solid start in their first innings. The hosts missed Jerome Taylor badly as both Kemar Roach and Shannon Gabriel failed to trouble Alastair Cook and Jonathan Trott with the new ball. Although Devendra Bishoo bowled well, both the England batsmen played him confidently to give the visitors the advantage at this stage of the match. In the process, Cook also surpassed Alec Stewart (8463) to become England's second highest run-getter in Tests.

Both umpires converge and check the light again. They decide to take the players off the field. Cook and Trott would be happy with that decision. That will be stumps as well. The England dressing room looks very happy as they applaud their openers, who are making their way back.

Tea, Day 2: Things weren't looking good for West Indies when they lost 4 wickets for 24 runs today, but this last wicket parntnership between Bishoo and Gabriel has given them a handy first innings total. Marlon Samuels was the pick of the batsmen for the hosts as he scored a hundred. Stuart Broad, who did not bowl well yesterday, bagged four wickets today. Both teams would be reasonably happy at this stage, but England would have wanted to end West Indies' first innings much earlier. Take a break and join us back for England's reply.

104.4   Moeen Ali to Devendra Bishoo, out Lbw!! End of a sensational 52-run stand. Flighted delivery from Ali, Bishoo gets down on one knee to sweep, misses and gets hit in line with the off stump, umpire Bruce Oxenford raised his finger immediately. Bishoo reviewed it, but the technology proved that the onfield umpire was right. Devendra Bishoo lbw b Moeen Ali 30(48) [4s-4]
Moeen Ali to Devendra Bishoo, THATS OUT!! Lbw!!

Bishoo has been given out LBW but he has reviewed it. No issues with Moeen Ali's footing. That looks very close, it should be missing the stumps for the onfield call to be overturned. The check for the inside edge, but looks like there was no bat involved. Hawk-Eye comes in, impact is umpire's call and it's umpire's call on the stumps as it clips the off stump.

Alright! We are all for the action to begin now.

Play is about to begin and the good news is that there is a lot of blue sky around now. Well, umpire Bruce Oxenford came out to have an inspection and he feels the outfield is still wet. He wants the groundstaff to dry out the outfield further by probably using a rope. So the latest news is that play will resume at 14:00.
13:31 Local Time, 17:31 GMT, 23:01 IST: The rain has stopped and play will restart at 13:50.

We had a delayed start due to rain once again. Captain Denesh Ramdin looked good in the short session of play that was possible before the rain returned. Marlon Samuels could not get going and is still three runs short of his 7th Test hundred. Hopefully, the rain stays away and we can start immediately after the lunch break.

Ben Stokes says, "We should have got more wickets yesterday. It was a 50-50 kind of day. Sometimes things can get fired up (talking about the banter with Marlon Samuels). We both are playing for our country. We are not going to stop, we are all very aggressive cricketers. Would be nice to stop him (Samuels) from scoring a hundred."

09:35 Local Time, 13:35 GMT, 19:05 IST: The rain is steady and the pitch has been covered. We will have a delayed start. Play was scheduled to begin 15 minutes earlier, at 09:45, today, but weather has played spoilsport again.
09:25 Local Time, 13:25 GMT, 18:55 IST: Oops! Just like yesterday, it has started to rain before start of play. Hopefully it is just a passing shower this time.
The forecast is much better than yesterday but there are a few rain clouds hovering over the ground at the moment. The groundsmen have covered the pitch as a precautionary measure.

James Anderson and Chris Jordan were the pick of the bowlers for the visitors yesterday. Alastair Cook would hope that Stuart Broad too joins the party. Moeen Ali could not stem the run flow and he certainly needs to hit the right areas and aid the pacers, especially after taking James Tredwell's place in the side.

Hello and a warm welcome to Day 2 of the second Test match. Marlon Samuels has held this West Indies innings together in tough conditions. He is now on the verge of recording his 7th hundred in Tests. Captain Denesh Ramdin gave him good company yesterday before play was stopped due to bad light. However, both will have to start afresh today and West Indies need them to get a big partnership. Life is certainly not going to be easy for them though. After a night's rest, the England bowlers will be fresh and there will be some swing on offer early in the morning.
That's it from us. Play will begin 15 minutes early tomorrow, at 09:45 local time. Looking forward to your company then. Goodbye!

With Shivnarine Chanderpaul too gifting his wicket away to Ben Stokes soon after, West Indies found themselves in deep trouble, but Jermaine Blackwood and Marlon Samuels survived a few close calls and registered a fifty partnership before England and Jordan successfully reviewed an LBW shout to dismiss the former. A while later, after Samuels crossed fifty, England, Stokes in particular, sledged Samuels and that got Samuels going as he batted aggressively and took the attack to England. Soon Samuels recorded a fifty partnership with skipper Denesh Ramdin. With light fading quickly, the umpires ruled that only spinners can be employed but England were reluctant to bowl spin at both ends. Hence, play could not carry on further.

Stumps, Day 1: Play began after a 105-minute rain delay. In overcast conditions, James Anderson bowled a big inswinger to knock over Kraigg Brathwaite. With Stuart Broad not bowling a consistent line, Alastair Cook introduced Chris Jordan into the attack. Jordan had Devon Smith dropped by Gary Ballance at leg slip, but he removed Smith in the same over. However, replays suggested that Smith had not edged the ball. Smith opted not to review because the bat hit the ground at the same time the ball passed the bat and he was not confident that he did not edge it. Just when Darren Bravo looked set for a big knock, he poked a Broad delivery to Cook at slip and threw his wicket away.

The players are leaving the field. Umpire Steve Davis takes the bails off. Looks like England didn't want to operate with spinners. Marlon Samuels walks off the field and hits the boundary cushions with his bat. Probably he wanted to complete his hundred today. The covers are brought on as a precautionary move. The umpires are still out there and it's officially stumps. Umpire Bruce Oxenford takes a reading again.

53.5   Jordan to Blackwood, out Lbw!! Timely wicket for the visitors. Good length delivery on the leg stump, Blackwood looks to play through mid-on, but because his front foot was planted across with the boot pointing towards cover, he got into a bit of a tangle. He missed the ball completely and was hit on the knee roll in line with middle and leg. Blackwood lbw b Jordan 26(58) [4s-5]

Huge shout for LBW, not given. England have reviewed. Was it sliding down the leg-side? No issues with Jordan's footing. There is no inside edge. Remember, it has to hit a good part of the leg stump for the on-field call to be overturned. It's hitting and Jordan has got his man. Good review from England.

Tea, Day 1: Another good session for England. Darren Bravo threw away yet another start as he poked a Stuart Broad delivery to Alastair Cook at first slip. Shivnarine Chanderpaul then gifted his wicket away when he chipped a Ben Stokes freebie straight to Moeen Ali. Marlon Samuels has battled hard and is looking determined to play a long innings. Take a break and join us back for the final session.

Big shout for LBW. England think about the review and decide to send it upstairs. Samuels offered no shot and this is going to be interesting. Is it doing too much? Oh no! Hawk-Eye says umpire's call and Samuels survives.

Welcome back for the second session. The players are out in the middle.

Lunch, Day 1: With enough help for the pacers, James Anderson bowled a big inswinger to knock over Kraigg Brathwaite. However, Stuart Broad wasn't consistent enough to mount the pressure. Chris Jordan came on and bowled well. He had Devon Smith dropped by Gary Ballance, but managed to remove Smith in the same over. Take a break and join us back at 13:25 for the second session.

Coming back to the Devon Smith wicket, the bat hit the ground as the ball passed the bat. Smith stood there for a while thinking if he should review. Probably because the bat hit the ground, he wasn't sure if he had actually hit it. Replays showed that there might have been a gap between bat and ball. If he had reviewed it, it would have been very interesting. Remember, there is not hot-spot or snicko and it would have been very difficult for the third umpire to overturn the on-field call.

Oops! The rain has returned but it is not that heavy. The covers are back on. Looks like the toss could be delayed. However, no official word yet!

A hundred was scored in each innings of the Test match. Ian Bell proved why he's the best batsman in this current England line-up with a gritty 143 in the first innings. In reply, when West Indies were in deep trouble 23-year-old Jermaine Blackwood fought hard and bailed the side of trouble by registering his maiden Test hundred. Gary Ballance then scored a fine hundred in the third innings of the game to bat West Indies out of the match. West Indies' ODI captain, Jason Holder, showed his class with the bat by scoring a brisk hundred under immense pressure when the England bowlers had their tails up.

James Anderson, one of the best fast bowlers around, had a memorable game in Antigua. In the second innings, when he found the outside of Denesh Ramdin, he surpassed Ian Botham to become England's highest wicket-taker in Tests. A few members of Anderson's family also celebrated the moment from the stands as the England players congratulated their hero on the field.

After an exciting draw in Antigua, the action now shifts to Grenada for the second game of this 3-match Test series. There was a light shower in the morning but the good news is that the rain has stopped and made way some bright sunshine. The covers have also been removed. Because of overnight rain, there could be a bit of moisture on the surface and it looks like there is a bit of grass cover as well. It is quite humid out there, which means there will be some swing on offer early on. So, like the first Test, will teams opt to field first? Let's wait and see. For now, let's look back at the first game.

Preview

After a Jason Holder-inspired thrilling draw in the first Test, West Indies and England will square off once again at the National Cricket Stadium at St George's, Grenada. Both teams had a few positives and an equal measure of negatives in the first Test. While West Indies will be looking to maintain their intensity over longer periods of play, England will be striving towards being more dominant.

Ian Bell, Gary Ballance, Jermaine Blackwood and Holder all scored tons but it was only England who looked like winning the Test. That West Indies managed to stave off defeat would give them a moral high but newer tests beckon both teams on Tuesday.

Venue: National Cricket Stadium, St George's, Grenada

Date: April 21, 2015 - Apr 25, 2015

Time: 1400 GMT

Team news

West Indies

Denesh Ramdin's team chartered a jailbreak in Antigua but they will know that only a much-improved performance would give them a chance of winning the series. Blackwood was a revelation for them in the first innings of that Test but the batting does look brittle without support. Partnerships will be the key and that is something the hosts will be keen to improve upon.

It helped matters that Ramdin himself stepped up on the last day to assist Holder in a key stand. The skipper has set the bar high and will expect his mates to follow suit. The heartening fact in the batting would be the form shown by the youngsters Devon Smith, Blackwood and Holder. The more experienced campaigners like Shivnarine Chanderpaul, Marlon Samuels and Darren Bravo will be expected to play to their potential. That does give the batting a solid look.

Kemar Roach was the standout performer with the ball in the first Test. In both innings he led the way and set the tone after early strikes by Jerome Taylor. Both of them were well backed up by Holder but Suleiman Benn was a disappointment, and as a result he has been dropped from the squad, which leaves Devendra Bishoo as the only specialist spinner. The pacers will be expected to hold their places.

Probable XI: 1 Kraigg Brathwaite, 2 Devon Smith, 3 Darren Bravo, 4 Marlon Samuels, 5 Shivnarine Chanderpaul, 6 Jermaine Blackwood, 7 Denesh Ramdin (capt/wk), 8 Jason Holder, 9 Kemar Roach, 10 Jerome Taylor, 11 Devendra Bishoo

England

Inarguably, Alastair Cook's men were better for a major part of the first Test but it is also inescapable that they failed to finish the Test. Just a three-day layover could prove difficult to overcome the disappointment of not going 1-0 up in the three-match series. However, the challenge will be to shake it off and start the process all over again. The opening pair of Cook and Jonathan Trott did not do anything of notice in the first Test. However, given their experience, the duo will get another shot at Grenada. It also helps their cause that Ballance, Joe Root, Bell, Ben Stokes and Jos Buttler all scored at least a fifty in Antigua. That largely overshadowed the brittleness at the top and England will be looking forward for the experienced duo to pull their weight as well.

James Anderson, who became England's all-time highest leading wicket-taker in Antigua, will no doubt be buoyed and even more confident of leading the attack. The pace trio of Anderson, Stuart Broad and Chris Jordan did a commendable job but it was James Tredwell who stole the show. The offspinner's consistent show and the added advantage of Root's part-time spin gives Cook enough depth. Their lack of penetration in the crucial second innings was largely due to good batting on a pretty lifeless pitch. Cook will be placing faith on the same men to come good in Grenada.

Probable XI: 1 Alastair Cook (capt), 2 Jonathan Trott, 3 Gary Ballance, 4 Ian Bell, 5 Joe Root, 6 Ben Stokes, 7 Jos Buttler (wk), 8 Chris Jordan, 9 Stuart Broad, 10 James Tredwell, 11 James Anderson

Stats and Trivia

Only two Tests have been played in the National Cricket Stadium before, the last of which was in 2009. West Indies drew one game and lost the next against Bangladesh in 2009.

Quotes

"There's talk of there being a bit more bounce here than in Antigua. West Indies swung the new ball nicely in both innings - so we have to use the new ball well and get a few wickets early - and we're going to have to change our plans, get a lot of men in front of the bat." - England's new vice-captainIan Bell discusses strategy

England (From): Alastair Cook(c), Jonathan Trott, Gary Ballance, Ian Bell, Joe Root, Moeen Ali, Jos Buttler(w), Ben Stokes, Chris Jordan, Stuart Broad, James Anderson, Adam Lyth, Jonathan Bairstow, Liam Plunkett, Mark Wood, Adil Rashid, James Tredwell

West Indies (From): Kraigg Brathwaite, Devon Smith, Darren Bravo, Marlon Samuels, Shivnarine Chanderpaul, Jermaine Blackwood, Denesh Ramdin(c/w), Jason Holder, Kemar Roach, Jerome Taylor, Shannon Gabriel, Devendra Bishoo, Carlos Brathwaite, Shai Hope
